    Highlights

    •
    The apparent average mesh size of the Escherichia coli chromosome is around 50 nm
    •
    The cytoplasm effectively acts as a poor solvent for the chromosome
    •
    Ribosome and DNA densities are negatively correlated within the nucleoid region
    •
    RNA/DNA segregation is associated with chromosome compaction

    Summary

    All cells fold their genomes, including bacterial cells, where the chromosome is compacted into a domain-organized meshwork called the nucleoid. How compaction and domain organization arise is not fully understood. Here, we describe a method to estimate the average mesh size of the nucleoid in Escherichia coli. Using nucleoid mesh size and DNA concentration estimates, we find that the cytoplasm behaves as a poor solvent for the chromosome when the cell is considered as a simple semidilute polymer solution. Monte Carlo simulations suggest that a poor solvent leads to chromosome compaction and DNA density heterogeneity (i.e., domain formation) at physiological DNA concentration. Fluorescence microscopy reveals that the heterogeneous DNA density negatively correlates with ribosome density within the nucleoid, consistent with cryoelectron tomography data. Drug experiments, together with past observations, suggest the hypothesis that RNAs contribute to the poor solvent effects, connecting chromosome compaction and domain formation to transcription and intracellular organization.

    Graphical abstract

    Keywords

    1. chromosome folding
    2. nucleoid
    3. solvent quality
    4. chromosome compaction
    5. domain organization
    6. DNA mesh size
    7. ribosome localization
    8. RNA

    Introduction

    All cells, regardless of their origin, must package and organize their genome in a small volume. Proper folding of the chromosomes is critical, as it affects many cellular processes, including gene expression, DNA repair, and chromosome segregation. Unlike eukaryotic cells, bacterial cells lack a nuclear membrane and do not package their chromosomal DNA into repeating structural units akin to nucleosomes. However, they still fold and concentrate their chromosomal material into a dynamic and organized DNA meshwork known as the nucleoid. In many bacterial species, including Escherichia coli, the nucleoid is found within a portion of the cytoplasmic space (Figure 1A) (Gray et al., 2019

    62.

    In this study, we adopt a simple polymer physics perspective of the cell by considering the cytoplasm as a polymer solution in which the polymer is the DNA and the solvent is everything else in the cytoplasm (e.g., water, metabolites, proteins, NAPs, ribosomes, and RNAs) (Figure 1A). That is, rather than describing how each potential factor structures the chromosome mechanistically, we account for this at the coarse-grained level by describing all effects of known and unknown factors that shape the chromosome as an effective solvent. It is well established that the three-dimensional (3D) conformation of a polymer is directly affected by the interaction between the polymer and its solvent (de Gennes, 1979
    38.
    de Gennes, P.G.
    Scaling concepts in polymer physics
    Cornell University Press, 1979
    Google Scholar
    ; Rubinstein, 2003
    118.
    Rubinstein, M.
    Polymer physics
    Colby, R.H. (Editor)
    Oxford University Press, 2003
    Crossref
    Google Scholar
    ). Based on the polymer-solvent interaction, the quality of a solvent is broadly classified into three types: good, ideal, and poor. In a good solvent, interactions between the polymer and the solvent are favored over interactions between polymer segments. Conversely, in a poor solvent, interactions between polymer segments are favored over their interactions with the solvent. When the repulsive and attractive interactions are balanced out (zero net interaction), the solvent is said to be ideal. How the bacterial cytoplasm (or eukaryotic nucleoplasm) behaves as a solvent for the chromosome remains an open question.
    Here, we develop a live-cell experimental approach to estimate the apparent average mesh size of the nucleoid and infer the effective solvent quality of the cytoplasm in E. coli. We then describe experiments and simulations that connect this macroscopic description of the cytoplasm to chromosome folding, transcription, and intracellular organization.

    Results

    Here, we considered the cell as a simple semidilute (i.e., concentrated) polymer solution in which the chromosome is assumed to be a random coil polymer and its solvent is everything in the cytoplasm except the DNA (Figure 1A). In polymer physics, a polymer solution is said to be semidilute when the polymer concentration is high enough that the polymer segments overlap to form a meshwork. The average mesh size (or correlation length) 𝜉 of such a meshwork depends not only on properties of the polymer (concentration, rigidity, molecular weight and monomer size) but also on the quality of the solvent (de Gennes, 1979

    Apparent average nucleoid mesh size in E. coli cells

    Given a 𝑐 ≈ 7 mg/mL, the next variable to determine was the mesh size (𝜉). Studies on biopolymer solutions and hydrogels have demonstrated that particles of size much smaller than the average mesh size diffuse freely through the meshwork (Axpe et al., 2019
    4.
    Axpe, E. ∙ Chan, D. ∙ Offeddu, G.S. ...
    A Multiscale Model for Solute Diffusion in Hydrogels
    Macromolecules. 2019; 52:6889-6897
    Crossref

    ; Cai et al., 2011
    21.

    Scopus (240)
    PubMed

    22.
    Carn, F. ∙ Boué, F. ∙ Djabourov, M. ...

    160.
    Wong, I.Y. ∙ Gardel, M.L. ∙ Reichman, D.R. ...
    Anomalous diffusion probes microstructure dynamics of entangled F-actin networks
    Phys. Rev. Lett. 2004; 92:178101
    Crossref
    Scopus (36)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). When the probe size is close to the average mesh size, the probe dynamics becomes impacted by the polymer mesh. This impact exacerbates with increasing probe size. In the context of the cell, this implies that probes much smaller than the nucleoid mesh size will diffuse freely in the cytoplasm without any apparent hindrance from the nucleoid (assuming that the particles do not interact with the nucleoid). Such probes will have an equal probability of diffusing inside or outside the nucleoid. In contrast, probes larger than the average mesh size will have a higher probability of diffusing outside the nucleoid, leading to greater nucleoid exclusion with increasing probe size.
    To probe the nucleoid mesh size, we first used an E. coli strain (CJW6340) that expresses a GFP-tagged, artificially designed protein that self-assembles into a 60-subunit dodecahedron nanocage of 25 nm (Figure 2A) (Hsia et al., 2016
    58.
    Hsia, Y. ∙ Bale, J.B. ∙ Gonen, S. ...
    Design of a hyperstable 60-subunit protein dodecahedron. [corrected]
    Nature. 2016; 535:136-139
    Crossref
    Scopus (187)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Basal expression of nanocage-GFP proteins (i.e., leaky synthesis) was sufficient to produce a single nanocage-GFP particle per cell in a fraction of the population (Figure 2B). Single-particle tracking experiments revealed no evidence of steric hindrance by the nucleoid, as the nanocage-GFP particle appeared to diffuse freely throughout the cytoplasm (Figure 2C; Video S1). The slope of the ensemble-averaged mean squared displacement (MSD) curve (n = 85 particle trajectories) was close to 1 in the log-log scale (Figure 2D), consistent with Brownian motion (note that the deviation of the MSD from the linearity at long-timescale is due to cell confinement). Furthermore, ensemble calculation of the relative positions of nanocage-GFP particles inside cells demonstrated that the probability density of nanocage-GFP localization is uniform throughout the cytoplasm (Figure 2E; n = 2,500 localizations). Thus, these 25-nm probes were neither trapped nor excluded by the nucleoid, consistent with their diffusion being Brownian. This result indicates that the apparent average nucleoid mesh size is >25 nm.

    We imaged GFP-μNS particles (n = 133,692) and calculated their relative positions in the corresponding cells from static images. We then binned all GFP-μNS particles by size and constructed probability density maps that indicate the likelihood of finding a GFP-μNS particle at a specific intracellular location across cells. For particles with the smallest average particle size (51 nm), the probability density map appeared almost indistinguishable from that obtained for nanocage-GFP particles (Figures 2E and 2F). This pattern changed in the next size bin, as probes of an average size of 58 nm started to display an increased probability to be localized at the cell pole regions (i.e., away from the nucleoid). This enrichment in probability density of localization at the cell poles continued to increase with probe size (Figures 2F and 2G), with ever-larger particles becoming less and less likely to be found within the nucleoid region. Particles with the largest average size (150 nm) were almost completely excluded from the nucleoid, as shown by the high probability density of localization at the cell poles and the near-zero probability density elsewhere in the cell. While these ensemble results cannot provide an exact value, they estimate the apparent average nucleoid mesh size to be around 50 nm.

    The E. coli cytoplasm behaves as a poor solvent for the chromosome

    Based on 𝑐 ≈ 7 mg/mL, 𝑏 ≈6 0 nm, and 𝜉 ≈ 50 nm, we found that the corresponding 𝜈 would be ∼0.36 (Equation 1). Such a small exponent (< 0.5) implies that the E. coli cytoplasm effectively behaves as a poor solvent for the chromosome. Since probes can start “feeling” a meshwork at sizes lower than the mesh size (Wong et al., 2004
    160.
    Wong, I.Y. ∙ Gardel, M.L. ∙ Reichman, D.R. ...
    Anomalous diffusion probes microstructure dynamics of entangled F-actin networks
    Phys. Rev. Lett. 2004; 92:178101
    Crossref
    Scopus (36)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), our 𝜉 value may be underestimated. However, a mesh size greater than 50 nm would result in an even smaller 𝜈 value. The conclusion that the cytoplasm acts as a poor solvent is also robust against variability in DNA concentration across cells (Figure 1E) or nutrient-poor or -rich growth conditions (see above). For instance, a DNA concentration of 8 mg/mL (or higher) would correspond to a smaller 𝜈 (Figure S3A). At DNA concentrations of 6 mg/mL or as low as 5 mg/mL,𝜈 would remain well below 0.5 (Figure S3A). In addition, our conclusion appears robust to reasonable variations in DNA Kuhn length due to potential fluctuations in cytoplasmic ionic strength. In our model, to achieve an apparent ∼50-nm mesh size in an ideal (𝜈 = 0.5) or good (𝜈 = 0.58) solvent, the Kuhn length of a polymer at an average concentration of 7 mg/mL would have to be 26 nm or 13 nm, respectively (i.e., persistence length ≤13 nm). Such a small value has not been observed experimentally even in solutions of extremely high ionic strength (e.g., 3–4 M NaCl) (Borochov et al., 1981
    13.
    Borochov, N. ∙ Eisenberg, H. ∙ Kam, Z.

    A poor solvent may promote chromosome domain formation

    Intriguingly, for 𝑏 ≈ 60 nm and 𝑐 ≈ 7 mg/mL, Equation 1 indicates that the average mesh size decreases as 𝜈 increases (i.e., as the solvent quality improves) (Figure S3A). To probe the potential origin of this dependence, we performed 3D Monte Carlo simulations of chromosome conformation (STAR Methods). For all simulations, we modeled the E. coli chromosome as a freely jointed phantom chain. The solvent quality was simply modeled by tuning the constraint on the range of angles between neighboring DNA segments (STAR Methods). These constraints were empirically chosen so that the power law scaling between the polymer radius of gyration and the number of segments had an exponent equal to 𝜈 = 0.36 (poor), 0.50 (ideal), and 0.58 (good) at small length scales (Figure S3B). Note that in a semidilute polymer solution, at large length scales, the interactions among monomers become screened such that the scaling exponent converges to 0.5 (Rubinstein, 2003
    118.
    Rubinstein, M.
    Polymer physics
    Colby, R.H. (Editor)
    Oxford University Press, 2003
    Crossref
    Google Scholar
    ); this crossover also occurs in our simulations (Figure S3B, inset). To achieve the average DNA concentration observed in actual nucleoids (7 mg/mL), we confined the entire chromosome within the average nucleoid volume (0.70 μm3) in B-period cells (Figure 1D).
    The simulations revealed a drastic difference in chromosomal conformation across the “solvent quality” conditions (Video S2). The DNA density appeared to be much more spatially heterogeneous in the poor solvent condition relative to the ideal and good solvent conditions. This was evident in cross-sectional slices of simulated chromosomes in which each dot represents a DNA segment crossing the plane (Figure 3A). The spatial heterogeneity of DNA density in the poor solvent condition compared to the other conditions was also apparent in the two-dimensional (2D) histograms showing the probability density of finding a DNA segment inside the nucleoid region (Figure 3B). Gratifyingly, this result is consistent with the spatial heterogeneity of DNA density observed in super-resolution fluorescence images of bacterial nucleoids (Le Gall et al., 2016

    This video shows a 3D overview of chromosomes simulated in confinement of a spherocylinder with a volume equal to that of an average nucleoid (∼0.7 μm3).     In the poor solvent simulations, DNA segments were often closer to each other, leading to the formation of regions with high DNA density interspersed with regions of low DNA density. This spatial heterogeneity in DNA density created “holes” (Figures 3A and 3B; Video S2), which may increase the apparent average mesh size and allow larger objects to pass through the nucleoid. Meanwhile, the DNA density of the nucleoid was more spatially homogeneous in the ideal and good solvent conditions (Figures 3A and 3B; Video S2), likely contributing to the smaller average mesh size.

To examine this more closely, we created average maps that show the average distances (over 10 simulations) between any given pair of DNA loci along the entire simulated chromosomes (Figure 3C) or a 500-kb region (Figure 3D) under a poor, ideal, or good solvent condition.     Spatial heterogeneity in ribosome density within the nucleoid correlates negatively with DNA density

    If an effective poor solvent quality promotes spatial heterogeneity of DNA density in the cell, this may, in turn, affect the spatial distribution of other cytoplasmic components, even within the nucleoid region.     Video S4. Comparison between the reference and the average structure of localized 70S ribosomes, related to Figure 4
    This video shows a 3D comparison between the low-pass filtered (∼3 nm resolution) reference structure (gray) obtained from (Fu et al., 2019) and the average structure (yellow) based on all ribosomes localized in the tomogram shown in Figure 4B and Video S3.
    Since DNA cannot be directly visualized in the tomograms, we turned to fluorescence microscopy to examine whether the spatial heterogeneity in ribosome density within the nucleoid region is associated with differences in DNA densities. We imaged DAPI-stained E. coli cells (CJW7020) producing 50S ribosomal protein L1 tagged with monomeric superfolder GFP (Figures 5A and 5B). As before, in each cell (n = 1,126), we identified the nucleoid outlines based on the DAPI signal (dotted lines in Figures 5A and 5B). When calculating the correlation between the DNA and ribosome fluorescence signals, we considered only image pixels well within the nucleoid region (at least two pixels away from the nucleoid outline; third row images in Figures 5A and 5B) to prevent any bias in the correlation analysis due to the well-known enrichment of ribosomes outside the nucleoid region. We found that even well within the nucleoid, the ribosome fluorescence signal correlates negatively with the DNA signal, as shown by two cell examples (Figures 5C and 5D). This was also observed at the population level (n = 1,126 cells, Figure 5E). These findings are consistent with the idea that the effective poor solvent quality of the cytoplasm contributes to the uneven DNA density, which, in turn, affects ribosome localization (or the other way around).

    An effective poor solvent quality contributes to significant chromosome compaction

    A polymer is intrinsically more compact in a poor solvent, because polymer segments preferentially interact with themselves rather than with the solvent. In our previous Monte Carlo simulations, the chromosome was modeled within the experimentally determined nucleoid volume (0.7 μm3) to keep the DNA concentration constant (i.e., 7 mg/mL) across solvent types. If our simulation approach reproduces expected solvent effects, then performing the same Monte Carlo simulations, this time in an unbounded space to allow the DNA concentration to change (STAR Methods), should result in simulated chromosomes being the most compact in the poor solvent condition. Simulation results validated this expectation (Video S5) and showed that the effective poor solvent quality of the cytoplasm can result in up to ∼60-fold chromosome compaction compared to a good solvent (Figure 6). We note that this solvent effect alone cannot explain the full compaction of a single chromosome inside cells, as the actual volume of a single-chromosome nucleoid in cells (Figure 1D) is still ∼10 times smaller (Figure 6, inset). This is not surprising given the simplicity of our model; it highlights the complexity of the cell and the multifactorial origin of chromosome compaction (see Discussion).

    Transcription may contribute to the effective poor solvent quality of the cytoplasm

Furthermore, rRNA synthesis is also impacted by these drug treatments. rRNA synthesis stops with transcription inhibition (Rif), while it persists when proteins synthesis (Cpl) is inhibited (Cole et al., 1987
    30.
    Cole, J.R. ∙ Olsson, C.L. ∙ Hershey, J.W. ...
    Feedback regulation of rRNA synthesis in Escherichia coli. Requirement for initiation factor IF2
    J. Mol. Biol. 1987; 198:383-392
    Crossref
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Hernandez and Bremer, 1990
    55.
    Hernandez, V.J. ∙ Bremer, H.
    Guanosine tetraphosphate (ppGpp) dependence of the growth rate control of rrnB P1 promoter activity in Escherichia coli
    J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265:11605-11614
    Abstract
    Full Text (PDF)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Kurland and Maaloe, 1962
    72.
    Kurland, C.G. ∙ Maaloe, O.
    Regulation of ribosomal and transfer RNA synthesis
    J. Mol. Biol. 1962; 4:193-210
    Crossref
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Thus, another mutually nonexclusive interpretation of the drug-induced phenotypes is that the chemical nature of the RNAs, and not exclusively the size of the polyribosomes, plays a role in controlling nucleoid size by affecting the effective solvent quality for the chromosome.
    If polyribosome crowding is the primary contributor of nucleoid compaction, then this hypothesis predicts that a reduced abundance in polyribosomes will lead to nucleoid expansion even when transcription is unaffected. To test this possibility, we treated E. coli cells with 5 mg/mL kasugamycin (Ksg), a translation initiation inhibitor of canonical RNAs (i.e., transcripts with a leader sequence) (Schluenzen et al., 2006
    121.
    Schluenzen, F. ∙ Takemoto, C. ∙ Wilson, D.N. ...
    The antibiotic kasugamycin mimics mRNA nucleotides to destabilize tRNA binding and inhibit canonical translation initiation
    Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2006; 13:871-878
    Crossref
    Scopus (91)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Tai et al., 1973
    139.
    Tai, P.C. ∙ Wallace, B.J. ∙ Davis, B.D.
    Actions of aurintricarboxylate, kasugamycin, and pactamycin on Escherichia coli polysomes
    Biochemistry. 1973; 12:616-620
    Crossref
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). At this concentration, Ksg has been shown to reduce the abundance of polyribosomes by converting a significant fraction of them into free ribosomal subunits and ribosome-free mRNAs (Bakshi et al., 2014
    7.
    Bakshi, S. ∙ Choi, H. ∙ Mondal, J. ...
    Time-dependent effects of transcription- and translation-halting drugs on the spatial distributions of the Escherichia coli chromosome and ribosomes
    Mol. Microbiol. 2014; 94:871-887
    Crossref
    Scopus (60)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Contrary to prediction, we found that DAPI-stained cells do not expand their nucleoids after incubation (40 min) with Ksg, unlike with Rif (Figures 7A and S6A). In fact, most nucleoids in Ksg-treated cells appeared more compact, consistent with a previous study (Bakshi et al., 2014
    7.
    Bakshi, S. ∙ Choi, H. ∙ Mondal, J. ...
    Time-dependent effects of transcription- and translation-halting drugs on the spatial distributions of the Escherichia coli chromosome and ribosomes
    Mol. Microbiol. 2014; 94:871-887
    Crossref
    Scopus (60)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Quantification of a time-course experiment in which cells were imaged after Rif or Ksg treatment for 20 to 80 min revealed a large overlap of size distributions between drug-treated and untreated cells (Figure 7B). The nucleocytoplasmic (NC) ratio (nucleoid area divided by cell area) increased following Rif treatment (Figure 7C), as expected for nucleoid expansion. In contrast, the NC ratio decreased over time in Ksg-treated cells (Figure 7C), indicative of nucleoid compaction. These results conflict with the polyribosome crowding hypothesis.
    In the drug experiments, we also imaged RNAs using SYTO RNASelect (Figures 7A and S6A), a fluorogenic RNA-specific dye that has been validated for use in live E. coli cells (Bakshi et al., 2014
    7.
    Bakshi, S. ∙ Choi, H. ∙ Mondal, J. ...
    Time-dependent effects of transcription- and translation-halting drugs on the spatial distributions of the Escherichia coli chromosome and ribosomes
    Mol. Microbiol. 2014; 94:871-887
    Crossref
    Scopus (60)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). For the untreated cell population, we found that the correlation between the RNASelect and DAPI signals varies across cells (Figure 7D), as quantified by the signal correlation factor (SCF) (Gray et al., 2019
    49.
    Gray, W.T. ∙ Govers, S.K. ∙ Xiang, Y. ...
    Nucleoid Size Scaling and Intracellular Organization of Translation across Bacteria
    Cell. 2019; 177:1632-1648.e1620
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (30)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). As expected (Bakshi et al., 2014
    7.
    Bakshi, S. ∙ Choi, H. ∙ Mondal, J. ...
    Time-dependent effects of transcription- and translation-halting drugs on the spatial distributions of the Escherichia coli chromosome and ribosomes
    Mol. Microbiol. 2014; 94:871-887
    Crossref
    Scopus (60)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), transcription inhibition by Rif led to a decrease in RNASelect signal (Figure 7A) (Bakshi et al., 2014
    7.
    Bakshi, S. ∙ Choi, H. ∙ Mondal, J. ...
    Time-dependent effects of transcription- and translation-halting drugs on the spatial distributions of the Escherichia coli chromosome and ribosomes
    Mol. Microbiol. 2014; 94:871-887
    Crossref
    Scopus (60)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), consistent with a reduced level of mRNAs due to their common short lifetime (Bernstein et al., 2002
    10.
    Bernstein, J.A. ∙ Khodursky, A.B. ∙ Lin, P.H. ...
    Global analysis of mRNA decay and abundance in Escherichia coli at single-gene resolution using two-color fluorescent DNA microarrays
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2002; 99:9697-9702
    Crossref
    Scopus (571)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The remaining RNASelect signal was positively correlated with the DAPI staining in Rif-treated cells (Figure 7D). In striking contrast, in Ksg-treated cells where the levels of mRNAs and rRNAs, respectively depleted of ribosomes or ribosomal proteins, are expected to increase, the RNASelect and DAPI signals appeared to segregate from each other (Figures 7A and S6A). This segregation gave rise to strongly negative SCF values (Figure 7D). A potential role for RNAs in compacting the nucleoid was also supported at the single-cell level. This was suggested by (1) the negative correlation between the RNASelect signal and the NC ratio across Ksg-treated cells (Figure 7E) and (2) the trend for cells with smaller NC ratios to have more negative SCF values between the RNASelect and DAPI signals (Figure 7E). We observed the same trends in untreated cells, albeit to a lesser degree (Figure S6B). These results may suggest the higher the RNA level, the greater the segregation between RNAs and DNA and the more compacted the nucleoid.
    We also noted a significant reduction in the fraction of cells with two discernable nucleoids in the Rif- and Ksg-treated populations relative to the untreated condition, as shown in demographs of cell populations (Figure 7F). For the Rif condition, this was easily explained by the expansion of the two nucleoids into the previously DNA-free internucleoid space. Such a trivial explanation could not apply to the Ksg condition, since Ksg compacts nucleoids over time. A reduced fraction in cells with two discernable nucleoids could also not be explained by a difference in cell size distribution (Figure 7B). To examine the origin of the phenotype, we performed time-lapse imaging on agarose pads containing Ksg. Nucleoids were visualized using a mCherry fusion to the NAP HU. We found that when cells started with two nucleoids, Ksg treatment often resulted in the nucleoids seemingly moving toward each other (Video S6) and almost coalescing (Video S7). This coalescence likely minimizes the interfacial interaction and promotes the separation between the nucleoid and RNA. Altogether, our results support the hypothesis that RNAs contribute to the effective poor solvent quality of the cytoplasm for the chromosome through an energetically unfavorable (i.e., repulsive) interaction between DNA and RNA.

    Discussion

    What may contribute to the effective poor solvent quality of the cytoplasm?

    Several factors are likely to contribute to the effective poor solvent quality of the cytoplasm. In our simplified view of the cell, the solvent is everything in the cytoplasm apart from the DNA polymer. In this context, NAPs are part of the solvent and therefore may be one of the factors due to their high abundance and well-known interactions with the chromosome. The potential role of NAPs may be direct or indirect. Some NAPs have been shown to bridge DNA segments or generate loops (Dame et al., 2019
    36.
    Dame, R.T. ∙ Rashid, F.M. ∙ Grainger, D.C.
    Chromosome organization in bacteria: mechanistic insights into genome structure and function
    Nat. Rev. Genet. 2019;
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Dillon and Dorman, 2010
    43.
    Dillon, S.C. ∙ Dorman, C.J.
    Bacterial nucleoid-associated proteins, nucleoid structure and gene expression
    Nat. Rev. Microbiol. 2010; 8:185-195
    Crossref
    Scopus (524)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), which may be macroscopically described as increasing polymer interaction. In addition, we speculate that NAPs, and potentially other DNA-binding proteins (such as transcriptional regulators), may act as an interface that indirectly modulates the chemical interaction between the chromosome and other components of the cytoplasm. Protein binding to the anionic DNA polymer could, for instance, locally alter the electrostatic potential of the chromosome. The effects may alter the compaction and mesh size of the nucleoid. It is important to note that NAP binding may also reduce the DNA Kuhn length, for instance, by bending, twisting or screening the DNA (Dame et al., 2019
    36.
    Dame, R.T. ∙ Rashid, F.M. ∙ Grainger, D.C.
    Chromosome organization in bacteria: mechanistic insights into genome structure and function
    Nat. Rev. Genet. 2019;
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Dillon and Dorman, 2010
    43.

    Bacterial nucleoid-associated proteins, nucleoid structure and gene expression
    Nat. Rev. Microbiol. 2010; 8:185-195
    Crossref
    Scopus (524)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In other instances, some NAPs may increase the DNA Kuhn length depending on their (local) concentration. For example, in vitro studies have shown that at low concentration, HU bends the DNA, locally increasing its flexibility (Skoko et al., 2004

While macromolecular crowding is widely believed to be play a major, if not the predominant, role in chromosome compaction, it is worth noting that the interpretations of the experimental data supporting this view are not always clear cut. As mentioned earlier, the well-known opposite effects of Rif and Cpl treatment on nucleoid size may be due to a change in not only polyribosome abundance but also RNA levels. According to the crowding hypothesis, Ksg treatment, which reduces polyribosome abundance (Bakshi et al., 2014
    7.
    Bakshi, S. ∙ Choi, H. ∙ Mondal, J. ...

As for proteins, their proposed role as crowders is primarily based on in vitro experiments showing that flexible uncharged polymers such as poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) condense isolated nucleoids (Cunha et al., 2001

    ). Under these fast-growth conditions, a large fraction of transcription is dedicated to rRNA synthesis at a few chromosomal locations. We speculate that this results in stronger compacting forces at sites of rRNA transcription relative to other chromosomal locations, producing unevenly shaped nucleoids. Comparatively, under slow-growth conditions, rRNA synthesis is reduced and transcription activities are more homogeneously distributed across the chromosome, potentially contributing to the smoother, more uniform nucleoid shape observed under these conditions.
    Among all of the potential factors involved, we find transcription particularly interesting for several reasons: (1) transcription is dictated by the sequence of the DNA, meaning that the polymer itself may be able to affect the quality of its own solvent; (2) transcription is tunable, which may contribute to differences in chromosome folding across environmental conditions and bacterial species; and (3) both DNA and RNA are strong polyanions.     ). Our simulations suggest that the effective poor solvent quality of the cytoplasm may promote the spontaneous formation of chromosomal domains (Figure 3; Video S2).
    In these simulations, the DNA has no sequence information. Therefore, domains can form anywhere along the DNA polymer, as shown by randomly averaging 10 different simulated chromosomes (Figure S7A). As a result of this stochasticity, boundaries between domains blurred with each other and became undefined when 100 distance maps of simulated chromosomes were averaged (Figure S7B). Note that the presence of domains remained apparent in the poor solvent relative to the good or ideal solvent, as shown by the thicker signal along the diagonal of the averaged map. However, the blurring of the domain boundaries in the 100-chromosome averaged map is in contrast with Hi-C contact maps in which boundaries of CIDs remain visible despite averaging over billions of cells. In light of our findings, we propose that domain boundaries may result, at least in part, from energetically unfavorable interactions between DNA and RNAs, particularly at sites of highly expressed genes where transcripts are abundant.     Chromosome-dependent intracellular organization and dynamics

    Bacteria lack nuclear membranes. As a result, the chromosome effectively functions as a mesh-like physical barrier that can affect the diffusion and spatial distribution of cytoplasmic components. Therefore, the mesh size of the nucleoid is an important length scale to consider. By assessing the degree of nucleoid exclusion for fluorescent probes of varying sizes (25–150 nm), we approximate the apparent average mesh size of the nucleoid to be around 50 nm in exponentially growing E. coli cells (Figure 2). This length scale has several physiological implications. For instance, it predicts that the diffusion and spatial distribution of cytoplasmic components close or larger than this estimate are impacted by the presence of the nucleoid in the cytoplasm. We anticipate that some (possibly most) polyribosome species belong to this category. This reasoning is consistent with the single-molecule studies showing that ribosomes, which are mostly found as polyribosomes (Dai et al., 2016

    ; Sanamrad et al., 2014

    Crossref
    Scopus (102)

    ).
    Note that our mesh size estimation reflects an average obtained from ensemble measurements. DNA density is known to be spatially heterogeneous within individual nucleoids (Le Gall et al., 2016

    ), consistent with our poor solvent simulations (Figure 3). We therefore expect the nucleoid to have a spectrum of mesh sizes with an average around 50 nm. We speculate that regions with smaller mesh sizes (i.e., more compacted DNA) represent regions that are less active in gene expression, while regions with larger mesh sizes (i.e., less compacted DNA) are more active. This is consistent with the negative correlation between ribosome and DNA densities at the nucleoid level (Figure 5).

    Limitations of the study

    This study only used E. coli cells in exponential phase. Our method should provide a mean to examine different conditions (e.g., stationary phase and antibiotic exposure) in various bacteria, as long as probes of varying size (e.g., GFP-μNS) can be expressed. Our simulation approach offers high computational efficiency and effectively reproduces the scaling of polymer size at different length scales (Figure S3; STAR Methods) and the DNA density heterogeneity across the nucleoid (Figure 3). However, it does not explicitly model the molecular forces among the monomers or interaction between distant monomers, which will be important to do in future work. In addition, we inferred the effective solvent quality of the cytoplasm for the chromosome by considering that the chromosome is a random coil polymer and the solvent is everything else in the cytoplasm. This simplification provides a macroscopic description of the cytoplasm that interconnect various aspects of cell and chromosome biology, from chromosome compaction (Figure 6) and transcription (Figure 7) to chromosome domain organization (Figure 3) and intracellular organization (Figures 2, 4, and 5). In reality, cells are far more complex than simple polymer solutions. The chromosome does not behave as simply as a random coiled polymer (Hadizadeh Yazdi et al., 2012
    51.
    Hadizadeh Yazdi, N. ∙ Guet, C.C. ∙ Johnson, R.C. ...
    Variation of the folding and dynamics of the Escherichia coli chromosome with growth conditions
    Mol. Microbiol. 2012; 86:1318-1333
    Crossref
    Scopus (91)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Wiggins et al., 2010
    154.
    Wiggins, P.A. ∙ Cheveralls, K.C. ∙ Martin, J.S. ...
    Strong intranucleoid interactions organize the Escherichia coli chromosome into a nucleoid filament
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2010; 107:4991-4995
    Crossref
    Scopus (134)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), in part due to enzymatic activity leading to DNA supercoiling (Deng et al., 2005
    41.
    Deng, S. ∙ Stein, R.A. ∙ Higgins, N.P.
    Organization of supercoil domains and their reorganization by transcription
    Mol. Microbiol. 2005; 57:1511-1521
    Crossref
    Scopus (104)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Postow et al., 2004
    110.
    Postow, L. ∙ Hardy, C.D. ∙ Arsuaga, J. ...
    Topological domain structure of the Escherichia coli chromosome
    Genes Dev. 2004; 18:1766-1779
    Crossref
    Scopus (310)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). As mentioned above, the proposed poor solvent effects likely originate from interspersed and superimposed molecular interactions associated with the complex and active nature of the cytoplasm. Further experimental and theoretical work will be required to disentangle the contribution of each factor.

    Method details

    Cultures

    To obtain steady-state growth conditions, a sample of an overnight liquid cell culture in stationary phase was diluted by a factor of at least 10,000 in the corresponding fresh growth medium (see below for the composition of the growth medium used for each experiment). The culture was then allowed to grow in an incubator shaker (New Brunswick Innova 44), at the indicated temperature, to reach an optical density at 600 nm (OD600) of 0.1-0.3 prior to microscopy. Details about growth conditions are described for each method section below.

    Light microscopy and image analysis

    Unless otherwise specified, all exponentially growing cells were imaged on 1% agarose pads supplemented with growth medium. When appropriate, cultures were incubated with 1 μg/ml 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) for 15 min in growth medium prior to imaging on agarose pads. Phase contrast and epifluorescence imaging were performed on a Nikon Eclipse Ti-E microscope equipped with a phase contrast Nikon CFI Plan Apo DM Lambda 100x oil objective (NA = 1.45), and a SOLA light engine (Lumencor). A Ph3 phase contrast ring was used. The following Chroma filters were used for epifluorescence imaging: DAPI (excitation D390/22x, dichroic T425lpxr, emission ET460/50 m), GFP (excitation ET470/40x, dichroic T495lpxr, emission ET525/50 m), mCherry/TexasRed (excitation ET560/40x, dichroic T585lp, emission ET630/75 m). The microscope was controlled by the NIS-Elements AR software.
    Using the open source software Oufti (Paintdakhi et al., 2016
    100.
    Paintdakhi, A. ∙ Parry, B. ∙ Campos, M. ...
    Oufti: an integrated software package for high-accuracy, high-throughput quantitative microscopy analysis
    Mol. Microbiol. 2016; 99:767-777
    Crossref
    Scopus (146)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), cell and nucleoid outlines were constructed based on the phase contrast and epifluorescence (e.g., DAPI) images, respectively. When appropriate, cells were classified into the B, C and D cell-cycle periods based on two cell features: SeqA-mCherry pattern and cell area, as described before (Gray et al., 2019
    49.

Since 𝑏 has a dimension of length and (𝜈−1)/(3⁢𝜈−1)+2⁢𝜈/(3⁢𝜈−1)=1, 𝜉 correctly has a dimension of length.

    Single-particle tracking experiments

    GFP-tagged nanocage particles were produced through basal expression of the GFP-tagged protein subunit I3-01 in E. coli cells (CJW6340) grown at 30°C in M9 minimal medium supplemented with glycerol (0.2%), casamino acids (0.1%) and thiamine (1 μg/ml). Phase contrast images were taken first to define cell outlines. Time-lapse fluorescence images were then acquired at a frame rate of 100 ms. Nanocage particles were localized and tracked using the MATLAB class SPT (see supplementary code). Briefly, an image was first smoothed by a band-pass filter. Potential regions containing the particles were then segmented based on an intensity threshold. Based on the region sizes, background noise pixels or particle clusters were filtered out. Within each of the remaining segmented regions, the brightest pixel was located. On the brightest pixel and its eight surrounding pixels, the pixel intensities were fitted by a 2D Gaussian distribution, whose center was taken as the estimated particle position. The particle locations were linked into trajectories using an algorithm described previously (Crocker and Grier, 1996
    33.
    Crocker, J.C. ∙ Grier, D.G.
    Methods of Digital Video Microscopy for Colloidal Studies
    J. Colloid Interface Sci. 1996; 179:298-310
    Crossref
    Scopus (2486)
    Google Scholar
    ). The 2D mean squared displacements (MSD) plot were calculated as 𝑀⁢𝑆⁢𝐷⁡(𝜏)=<(𝑟⁡(𝑡+𝜏)−𝑟⁡(𝑡))2>, where 𝜏 is a given time delay and𝑟⁡(𝑡) and 𝑟⁢(𝑡+𝜏) denote the particle positions before and after the given time delay. Similarly, GFP-μNS particles were produced through IPTG induction (50-200 μM) for a duration of 30-120 min, in E. coli cells (CJW4617) grown at 30°C in M9 minimal medium supplemented with glycerol (0.2%), casamino acids (0.1%) and thiamine (1 μg/ml). GFP-μNS particles were detected using SpotFinder (Sliusarenko et al., 2011
    130.
    Sliusarenko, O. ∙ Heinritz, J. ∙ Emonet, T. ...
    High-throughput, subpixel precision analysis of bacterial morphogenesis and intracellular spatio-temporal dynamics
    Mol. Microbiol. 2011; 80:612-627
    Crossref
    Scopus (340)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Particle positions of both nanocage-GFP and GFP-μNS particles relative to the cell coordinates were calculated using the function projectToMesh in Oufti and normalized by cell width and length. The relative particle positions were used to generate histograms to demonstrate the probability density of relative particle locations inside the cell.

    Monte Carlo simulation of chromosome conformation

    The entire E. coli chromosome (4.6 million base pairs, contour length = 1564 μm) was modeled as a freely-jointed phantom chain (zero volume, no self-avoidance) of 26,066 segments, each of which had a length of 60 nm (to reflect the estimated Kuhn length). In each simulation instance, the first segment of the chromosome was constructed by linking the origin (x = 0, y = 0, z = 0) and a random point radially a Kuhn-length (i.e., 60 nm) away. Similarly, the remaining segments were constructed iteratively by linking the current end of the chromosome chain with another randomly sampled point that was radially a Kuhn-length away. The solvent quality was modeled by the constraint on the range of angles between consecutive segments. In the ideal-solvent case, there was no restriction on the inter-segmental angles (𝜃), as there was no preference for a segment to interact with other parts of the polymer or the solvent. Meanwhile, for a polymer in a poor or good solvent, the segments on the polymer chain was set to ‘prefer’ interacting among themselves (poor solvent) or with the solvent (good solvent). To model the attraction and repulsion, restrictions were applied to the range of possible 𝜃. By verifying the power-law scaling between the number of segments and the radius of gyration of the simulated chromosomes, the 𝜃 was constrained within empirically determined ranges (Figure S3B). Specifically, we found that the Flory exponents (0.36 and 0.58) could be achieved when the inter-segmental angles were constrained to be greater than 11π/18 and smaller than π/2, respectively. A limitation of our simulation scheme is that it does not explicitly model the molecular forces among the monomers and only considers interaction between adjacent monomers. However, it is computationally efficient for modeling a large polymer like the bacterial chromosome and effectively reproduces the scaling of polymer size at two length scales. Specifically, at small length scales, the conformation (and thus 𝑅𝑔) of a small section of the polymer chain in a semidilute solution behaves similarly to that in a dilute solution at a given solvent quality (Figure S3B), as monomers are surrounded mostly by the solvent at small length scales (Rubinstein, 2003
    118.
    Rubinstein, M.
    Polymer physics
    Colby, R.H. (Editor)
    Oxford University Press, 2003
    Crossref
    Google Scholar
    ). At larger length scales (Figure S3B, inset), interactions between distant monomers become screened and the polymer behaves as a random walk, leading to a scaling exponent of 0.50 regardless of the solvent quality (Rubinstein, 2003
    118.
    Rubinstein, M.
    Polymer physics
    Colby, R.H. (Editor)
    Oxford University Press, 2003
    Crossref
    Google Scholar
    ).
    In order to compare the degree of chromosome compaction as a result of different types of solvent, the E. coli chromosome was simulated in free space 1,000 times for each type of the solvent. The radius of gyration of each simulated chromosome was calculated as 𝑅2𝑔=1𝑁⁢∑𝑁𝑖(𝑟𝑖−𝑟𝑚⁢𝑒⁢𝑎⁢𝑛)2, where 𝑅𝑔 is the radius of gyration, 𝑟𝑖 is position of 𝑖-th segment, 𝑟𝑚⁢𝑒⁢𝑎⁢𝑛 is the average position of all segments and 𝑁 is the total number of segments. Given a fixed contour length, the geometric constraint of being circular forces the chromosome to adopt a smaller average size compared to that of a linear chain. Quantitatively, the average radius of gyration of a circular polymer is a factor of √2 smaller than that of its linear counterpart (Casassa, 1965
    23.
    Casassa, E.F.
    Some statistical properties of flexible ring polymers
    J. Polym. Sci. A1. 1965; 3:605-614
    Google Scholar
    ; Kramers, 1946
    69.
    Kramers, H.A.
    The Behavior of Macromolecules in Inhomogeneous Flow
    J. Chem. Phys. 1946; 14:415-424
    Crossref
    Google Scholar
    ; Rubinstein, 2003
    118.
    Rubinstein, M.
    Polymer physics
    Colby, R.H. (Editor)
    Oxford University Press, 2003
    Crossref
    Google Scholar
    ; Zimm and Stockmayer, 1949
    171.
    Zimm, B.H. ∙ Stockmayer, W.H.
    The Dimensions of Chain Molecules Containing Branches and Rings
    J. Chem. Phys. 1949; 17:1301-1314
    Crossref
    Google Scholar
    ). Therefore, to account for the circular geometry of the E. coli chromosome, 𝑅𝑔 was divided by a factor of √2 to get 𝑅′𝑔. The volume of the simulated nucleoid in each type of solvent was calculated as 𝑉=43⁢𝜋⁢(𝑅′𝑔)3.
    To examine chromosome conformation across solvents under the experimentally determined average DNA concentration within the nucleoid region (Figures 3, S7A, and S7B), we performed the simulations described above, except that the entire chromosome chain was confined within a spherocylindrical space with a volume (0.70 μm3) equal to the experimentally observed average nucleoid volume in B-period cells.
    To model the DNA relaxation at the domain boundary in a poor solvent (Figure S7D), the restriction on 𝜃 was altered to a different range among a number (𝑛) of DNA segments surrounding the 1-, 2-, 3- and 4-Mb coordinates of the chromosome during simulation. The variables 𝜃 and 𝑛 therefore set the degree and length (𝐿) of the DNA relaxation, respectively.

    Cryo-FIB milling

    The plunge-frozen grids were clipped into cryo-FIB AutoGrids and mounted into the specimen shuttle under liquid nitrogen. An Aquilos cryo-FIB system (Thermo Fisher Scientific) was used to mill the samples to produce thin lamellae. The samples were first sputter-coated with Pt (1 kV, 15 mA, 15 s) to improve the overall sample conductivity, and then were deposited by an organometallic Pt layer (4-5 μm thick) using the gas injection system for the sample protection. Lamellae were produced using the gallium ion beam at 30 kV with stage tilt angle around 17°. The ion beam current was reduced according to the lamella thickness (t) during the milling process: 0.5 nA for t ≥ 3 μm, 0.3 nA for t ≥ 1 μm, 0.1 nA for t ≥ 700 nm, 0.05/0.03 nA for final polishing. Afterward, a thin Pt layer was sputter-coated (1 kV, 10 mA, 5 s) on the lamella to prevent possible charging issue during the cryo-ET imaging.

    Cryo-ET data acquisition and tomogram reconstruction

    The cryo-FIB lamellae were transferred to a 300 kV Titan Krios electron microscope (Thermo Fisher Scientific) equipped with a Direct Electron Detector and energy filter (Gatan). The program SerialEM (Mastronarde, 2005
    90.
    Mastronarde, D.N.
    Automated electron microscope tomography using robust prediction of specimen movements
    J. Struct. Biol. 2005; 152:36-51
    Crossref
    Scopus (1782)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) was used to collect single-axis tilt series around −6 μm defocus, with a cumulative dose of ∼100 e-/Å covering angles from −60° to 60° (2° tilt step). Images were acquired at 26,000 × magnification with an effective pixel size of 5.457 Å at the specimen level. All recorded images were first drift corrected by the software MotionCor2 (Zheng et al., 2017
    169.
    Zheng, S.Q. ∙ Palovcak, E. ∙ Armache, J.P. ...
    MotionCor2: anisotropic correction of beam-induced motion for improved cryo-electron microscopy

    Scopus (1982)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and then stacked by the software package IMOD (Kremer et al., 1996
    70.
    Kremer, J.R. ∙ Mastronarde, D.N. ∙ McIntosh, J.R.
    Computer visualization of three-dimensional image data using IMOD
    J. Struct. Biol. 1996; 116:71-76
    Crossref
    Scopus (3066)

    Google Scholar
    ). All tilt series were then aligned by IMOD with the patching tracking method. The program Gctf (Zhang, 2016

    Gctf: Real-time CTF determination and correction
    J. Struct. Biol. 2016; 193:1-12

    ) was used to determine the defocus of each tilt image in the aligned stacks, and the function “ctfphaseflip” in IMOD was used to perform the contrast transfer function (CTF) correction for the tilt images. Tomograms were then reconstructed in IMOD using the CTF-corrected and aligned stacks. In total, we collected 11 tomograms and selected those that have the following two characteristics: 1) a cell-like shape (i.e., the lamella spans the length of the cell), and 2) least amount of iced dirt and crystalline ice.

    Quantification and statistical analysis

    Quantification of cell and nucleoid characteristics

    Cell characteristics (cell size, nucleoid size, fluorescence signal intensities etc.) were obtained by analyzing phase and fluorescence images using the software package Oufti (Paintdakhi et al., 2016

    Calculation of correlation coefficients

    Correlation coefficients (Spearman’s 𝜌) between variables (i.e., DAPI pixel intensity versus GFP pixel intensity, NC ratio versus RNASelect fluorescence density) were calculated using the built-in MATLAB function corr.

    Estimation of the DNA Kuhn length

    The Kuhn length of a polymer, 𝑏, is equivalent to twice its persistence length, which is a measure of rigidity. DNA is a semiflexible polymer. Its rigidity stems from base stacking interactions within the DNA duplex and electrostatic repulsion among phosphate groups in the DNA backbone. The persistence length of the DNA is often assumed to be 50 nm (i.e., Kuhn length 𝑏 = 100 nm). However, in vitro measurements of DNA rigidity indicate that the presence of multivalent cations, including Mg2+, the most abundant divalent cation in E. coli (Alatossava et al., 1985
    2.

The cell volume was calculated by accumulating the volume of cylindrical slices along the cell center line. Each cylindrical slice was defined by the rotation of consecutive pairs of points in the cell outlines constructed by the Oufti software (Paintdakhi et al., 2016
    100.
    Paintdakhi, A. ∙ Parry, B. ∙ Campos, M. ...
    Oufti: an integrated software package for high-accuracy, high-throughput quantitative microscopy analysis
    Mol. Microbiol. 2016; 99:767-777
    Crossref
    Scopus (146)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). To construct the nucleoid outlines, Oufti first convolves the background-subtracted fluorescence image with a Laplacian of Gaussian. The convolution product was up-sampled using a cubic spline. The up-sampled pixels with zero-crossing components are then connected to form polygons that define the nucleoid contours (Paintdakhi et al., 2016
    100.
    Paintdakhi, A. ∙ Parry, B. ∙ Campos, M. ...
    Oufti: an integrated software package for high-accuracy, high-throughput quantitative microscopy analysis
    Mol. Microbiol. 2016; 99:767-777
    Crossref
    Scopus (146)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The nucleoid and cell areas were calculated by summing up the areas of the polygons defined by the nucleoid and cell outlines. The power 3/2 was used to convert the estimated nucleoid area fraction into a volume fraction. The nucleoid volume estimation was performed at the single-cell level, as was the DNA concentration calculation, which was simply a division between the estimated DNA mass and the nucleoid volume. Note that the exclusion of the largest GFP-μNS probes (150 nm) from the nucleoid gave us an independent method to estimate the nucleocytoplasmic (NC) ratio (𝐴𝑛⁢𝑢⁢𝑐⁢𝑙⁢𝑒⁢𝑜⁢𝑖⁢𝑑/𝐴𝑐⁢𝑒⁢𝑙⁢𝑙). Based on the cumulative distribution function of the GFP-μNS localizations, cell regions with the highest 30% localization density was considered as the cell pole and periphery. The total area of these regions was subtracted from the cell area to obtain the estimated nucleoid area. Using this method, we estimated that NC ratio = 0.67, which is close to the value obtained when the nucleoid area is defined by the Oufti outline of the DAPI staining of the cell. To verify that B-period cells are transcriptionally active, we used a strain (CJW7039) in which ribosomes are fluorescently labeled. CJW7039 cells were grown at 37°C in M9 minimal medium supplemented with glycerol (0.2%). Following DAPI staining and imaging, we did not see any large differences in nucleoid exclusion for ribosomes between cells in B, C and D periods as shown by the strongly overlapping distribution of the SCF values between nucleoid and ribosomes (Figure S1C). The SCF measures the pixel correlation between signals of fluorescently labeled nucleoid and ribosomes (Gray et al., 2019
    49.
    Gray, W.T. ∙ Govers, S.K. ∙ Xiang, Y. ...
    Nucleoid Size Scaling and Intracellular Organization of Translation across Bacteria
    Cell. 2019; 177:1632-1648.e1620
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (30)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Positive values represent mixing between the DNA and ribosomes, and negative values indicate that ribosomes are enriched outside the nucleoid. The fact that the SCF values in B-period cells are primarily negative indicates that polysomes are present and thus that transcription is ongoing. If transcription was not ongoing, the SCF values would be positive, as observed when transcription is inhibited by rifampicin (Figure S1C).

    Estimation of the average DNA concentration within nucleoids of E. coli in nutrient-rich conditions

    Bulk studies using the diphenylamine colorimetric assay and cell counting reported that the average DNA mass per cell under nutrient-rich conditions, glucose, glucose plus casamino acids and rich defined medium plus glucose as carbon sources, were around 10, 14 and 30 fg, respectively (Basan et al., 2015
    8.
    Basan, M. ∙ Zhu, M. ∙ Dai, X. ...
    Inflating bacterial cells by increased protein synthesis
    Mol. Syst. Biol. 2015; 11:836
    Crossref
    Scopus (69)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The average cell sizes among these growth conditions (i.e., 2.32, 3.33, 6.60 μm3, respectively) were also shown to scale linearly with the average DNA mass per cell (Basan et al., 2015
    8.
    Basan, M. ∙ Zhu, M. ∙ Dai, X. ...
    Inflating bacterial cells by increased protein synthesis
    Mol. Syst. Biol. 2015; 11:836
    Crossref
    Scopus (69)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Taking into consideration of the strong scaling between the nucleoid size and cell size (Gray et al., 2019
    49.
    Gray, W.T. ∙ Govers, S.K. ∙ Xiang, Y. ...
    Nucleoid Size Scaling and Intracellular Organization of Translation across Bacteria
    Cell. 2019; 177:1632-1648.e1620
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (30)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), we estimated the average DNA concentration within the nucleoid to be 7.3, 7.1 and 7.7 mg/ml under these three nutrient-rich growth conditions. Therefore, when taken together, the DNA concentration within the nucleoid among these nutrient-rich conditions is 7.4 ± 0.2 mg/ml.

    Estimation of GFP-μNS particle sizes

    The size estimation of the GFP- μNS particles was performed as previously described (Parry et al., 2014
    101.
    Parry, B.R. ∙ Surovtsev, I.V. ∙ Cabeen, M.T. ...
    The bacterial cytoplasm has glass-like properties and is fluidized by metabolic activity
    Cell. 2014; 156:183-194
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (370)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). This method establishes a relation between the fluorescence intensity (𝐼) of GFP-μNS particles and their absolute sizes (𝑑). The particle fluorescence intensity (𝐼) was calculated by integrating the volume of the fitting 2D Gaussian distribution that was used to determine the particle location: 𝐼=2⁢𝜋⁢𝐴⁢𝜎2, where 𝐴 and 𝜎 are the height and width of the fitting distribution, respectively (Sliusarenko et al., 2011
    130.
    Sliusarenko, O. ∙ Heinritz, J. ∙ Emonet, T. ...
    High-throughput, subpixel precision analysis of bacterial morphogenesis and intracellular spatio-temporal dynamics
    Mol. Microbiol. 2011; 80:612-627
    Crossref
    Scopus (340)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Assuming the total fluorescence intensity of a particle is proportional to its volume, and the volume is a cubic function of its size (e.g., for a sphere), we further calculated the cubic root of the fluorescence intensity: 3√𝐼.
    The absolute sizes of GFP-μNS particles were estimated as previously described (Parry et al., 2014
    101.
    Parry, B.R. ∙ Surovtsev, I.V. ∙ Cabeen, M.T. ...
    The bacterial cytoplasm has glass-like properties and is fluidized by metabolic activity
    Cell. 2014; 156:183-194
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (370)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Briefly, cells expressing GFP-μNS were lysed with T7 phages, resulting in the release of the GFP-μNS particles in solution. Cell debris were removed by centrifugation at 4,000 g. Released GFP-μNS particles were then mixed with fluorescent microspheres of known nominal size (110 nm, FluoSpheres F8803, Invitrogen), and their diffusion coefficients were determined using single particle tracking microscopy. We defined the fluorescence-derived relative particle size 𝑑𝑟⁢𝑒⁢𝑙=3√𝐼/𝐼𝑓⁢𝑙⁢𝑢⁢𝑜 for the GFP-μNS particles, where 𝐼𝑓⁢𝑙⁢𝑢⁢𝑜 denotes the average fluorescence intensity of the fluorescent microspheres. Based on the Stokes-Einstein equation, the relative particle size and the corresponding diffusion coefficient is inversely proportional: 𝐷=𝑘⁢𝑇/(3⁢𝜋⁢𝜂⁢𝑑𝑟⁢𝑒⁢𝑙), where 𝑘 is the Boltzmann constant, 𝑇 is the absolute temperature, and 𝜂 is the viscosity of the solution. The absolute sizes of the GFP-μNS particles were estimated as 𝑑=𝑑𝑓⁢𝑙⁢𝑢⁢𝑜⁢𝐷𝑓⁢𝑙⁢𝑢⁢𝑜⁢𝛼/𝐷, where 𝑑𝑓⁢𝑙⁢𝑢⁢𝑜 = 110 nm and 𝛼 = 𝑑/𝑑𝑟⁢𝑒⁢𝑙 is a calibration constant, which was found to be 685 nm.

    Construction of probability density maps for nanocage-GFP and GFP-μNS particles

    To construct the probability density maps of nanocage-GFP particle positions, we first calculated the particle positions (n = 2,500) relative to the cell outlines. All relative particle positions were then aggregated together and plotted as a normalized 2D histogram. For GFP-μNS particles, the particle positions (n = 133,692) were first grouped together (i.e., binned) based on the corresponding estimated particle sizes. For a given group of positions obtained from particles of similar estimated sizes, we calculated the relative positions to the cell outlines. For each group, we then plotted the particle positions as a normalized 2D histogram, representing a probability density map of the positions.

    Estimation of exclusion scores for nanocage-GFP and GFP-μNS particles

    Based on the cumulative distribution function of the GFP-μNS localizations in the bin of the largest particle size (150 nm), cell regions with the highest 30% localization density was assumed to be the non-nucleoid region (i.e., the cell pole and periphery), and the rest was assumed to be the nucleoid region. The average probability density of localizing the nanocage-GFP and GFP-μNS particles of different sizes within (𝑓𝑖⁢𝑛) and outside (𝑓𝑜⁢𝑢⁢𝑡) the assumed nucleoid regions were calculated. The exclusion score was calculated as 1−(𝑓𝑖⁢𝑛/𝑓𝑜⁢𝑢⁢𝑡).

    Pixel intensity correlation between the DNA and ribosome fluorescence signals

    E. coli cells (CJW7020) were grown at 37°C in M9 minimal medium supplemented with glucose (0.2%), casamino acids (0.1%) and thiamine (1 μg/ml). The nucleoid was visualized through DAPI straining. Fluorescence signals from DAPI and L1-msfGFP were acquired. The nucleoid outlines were constructed using objectDetection in the software package Oufti (Paintdakhi et al., 2016
    100.
    Paintdakhi, A. ∙ Parry, B. ∙ Campos, M. ...
    Oufti: an integrated software package for high-accuracy, high-throughput quantitative microscopy analysis
    Mol. Microbiol. 2016; 99:767-777
    Crossref
    Scopus (146)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In order to exclusively quantify the pixel intensity correlation within the nucleoid region, the nucleoid outlines were shrunk by 2 pixels from the original boundaries using the built-in MATLAB function polybuffer. The shrunk nucleoid outlines enclosed, on average, about 30% of the inner most pixels defined by the original outlines. Image masks were constructed using the shrunk nucleoid outlines, and pixels from both the DAPI and GFP images were extracted. Correlation scores (Spearman’s 𝜌) were then calculated between the intensities of DAPI and GFP pixels using the built-in MATLAB function corr.

    Construction of DAPI demographs

    The signal profiles of DAPI were calculated for individual cells using the software package Oufti (Paintdakhi et al., 2016
    100.
    Paintdakhi, A. ∙ Parry, B. ∙ Campos, M. ...
    Oufti: an integrated software package for high-accuracy, high-throughput quantitative microscopy analysis
    Mol. Microbiol. 2016; 99:767-777
    Crossref
    Scopus (146)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). For each cell, the DAPI signal profile was normalized as 𝐼𝑛⁢𝑜⁢𝑟⁢𝑚=(𝐼−𝐼𝑚⁢𝑖⁢𝑛)/(𝐼𝑚⁢𝑎⁢𝑥−𝐼𝑚⁢𝑖⁢𝑛), where 𝐼, 𝐼𝑛⁢𝑜⁢𝑟⁢𝑚, 𝐼𝑚⁢𝑖⁢𝑛, and 𝐼𝑚⁢𝑎⁢𝑥 are the raw, normalized, minimum and maximum values of the signal, respectively. The normalized signal profiles were further interpolated linearly using the built-in MATLAB function interp1 to obtain a fixed signal profile length. The signal profiles then sorted based on the corresponding cell length. All signal profiles were then concatenated to construct the final demograph plots.

    Implementation and quantification of Monte Carlo simulations

    The simulation of chromosomes was implemented and quantified in Python 3.6, with the additional libraries NumPy (Harris et al., 2020
    52.
    Harris, C.R. ∙ Millman, K.J. ∙ van der Walt, S.J. ...
    Array programming with NumPy
    Nature. 2020; 585:357-362
    Crossref
    Scopus (800)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), SciPy (Virtanen et al., 2020
    147.
    Virtanen, P. ∙ Gommers, R. ∙ Oliphant, T.E. ..., SciPy 1.0 Contributors
    SciPy 1.0: fundamental algorithms for scientific computing in Python
    Nat. Methods. 2020; 17:261-272
    Crossref
    Scopus (3027)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ), Matplotlib (Hunter, 2007
    59.
    Hunter, J.D.
    Matplotlib: A 2D Graphics Environment
    Comput. Sci. Eng. 2007; 9:90-95
    Crossref
    Scopus (9418)
    Google Scholar
    ) and pandas (McKinney, 2010
    91.
    McKinney, W.
    Data Structures for Statistical Computing in Python
    Proceedings of the 9th Python in Science Conference. 2010;
    Crossref
    Google Scholar
    ). Specifically, the simulation was implemented using base functions in Python 3.6 and NumPy library. SciPy and pandas were used to analyze all simulations and provide the corresponding statistics (e.g., confidence interval, mean radius of gyration) relevant to the simulated chromosomes. Matplotlib was used to graph the simulated chromosome data.

    Construction of distance maps for simulated DNA segments

    The simulated chromosomes were binned by approximately 10 kb (56 DNA segments), and the average positions of the segments within each bin were calculated. The binning was applied to reduce the computational complexity of calculating the pair distance between DNA segments by more than three orders of magnitude. A matrix of pair distances, where the 𝑖-th row and 𝑗-th column represent the Euclidean distance between the 𝑖-th and 𝑗-th bins, was constructed for every simulated chromosome (obtained from independent simulation runs). A chosen number (10, 100 or 1000) of such matrices were averaged together to generate distance maps representing the average pair distances between the binned segments, which were then visualized as images in which the individual pixels correspond to the distances.

    Ribosome localization in the cryo-ET tomograms

    The software package emClarity (Himes and Zhang, 2018
    56.
    Himes, B.A. ∙ Zhang, P.
    emClarity: software for high-resolution cryo-electron tomography and subtomogram averaging
    Nat. Methods. 2018; 15:955-961
    Crossref
    Scopus (56)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) was used to perform the 3D template search to identify ribosomes from the tomograms. A low-pass filtered (∼4-nm resolution) E. coli 70S ribosome structure (Fu et al., 2019
    47.
    Fu, Z. ∙ Indrisiunaite, G. ∙ Kaledhonkar, S. ...
    The structural basis for release-factor activation during translation termination revealed by time-resolved cryogenic electron microscopy
    Nat. Commun. 2019; 10:2579
    Crossref
    Scopus (17)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) was used as a reference for the template search (Figure S4C). Initially, up to 15,000-20,000 sub-tomograms were initially selected from each tomogram. Subsequently, the sub-tomograms (80 × 80 × 80 voxel) were extracted from the CTF-corrected tomograms with no binning and the 3D classification and alignment were applied to all sub-tomograms by the software package i3 (Winkler, 2007
    155.
    Winkler, H.
    3D reconstruction and processing of volumetric data in cryo-electron tomography
    J. Struct. Biol. 2007; 157:126-137
    Crossref
    Scopus (98)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ; Winkler et al., 2009
    156.
    Winkler, H. ∙ Zhu, P. ∙ Liu, J. ...
    Tomographic subvolume alignment and subvolume classification applied to myosin V and SIV envelope spikes
    J. Struct. Biol. 2009; 165:64-77
    Crossref
    Scopus (82)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) with no binning. Sub-tomograms of the particles in the false class were removed (Figure S4D). After that, for every pair of localized structures, the separation distance between their center mass was calculated. Two structures in a pair were considered duplicates, if the distance between their centers of mass was smaller than 20 nm, and the structure that had a lower cross-correlation score with the global average structure was removed. This process repeated itself until no duplicate structure was found. The program UCSF ChimeraX (Goddard et al., 2018
    48.
    Goddard, T.D. ∙ Huang, C.C. ∙ Meng, E.C. ...
    UCSF ChimeraX: Meeting modern challenges in visualization and analysis
    Protein Sci. 2018; 27:14-25
    Crossref
    Scopus (840)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) was used for the 3D surface rendering of subtomogram average structure of ribosome (Figure 4C; Video S4). The accuracy of the localization of ribosomes was verified by both visual inspection and comparison of the average structure obtained from the localized ribosomes to the reference structure. Ribosome statistics for each analyzed lamella are provided in Figure S5A.

    Classification of polyribosomes in tomograms

    The information on ribosome positions and orientations generated by i3 from the previous localization steps were first transferred to RELION (Bharat and Scheres, 2016
    11.
    Bharat, T.A. ∙ Scheres, S.H.
    Resolving macromolecular structures from electron cryo-tomography data using subtomogram averaging in RELION
    Nat. Protoc. 2016; 11:2054-2065
    Crossref
    Scopus (72)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). All sub-tomograms were re-extracted from the CTF-corrected tomograms with a larger size (200 × 200 × 200 voxel) to include the potential neighboring ribosomes. The CTF volumes in RELION were used for missing wedge compensation and dose weighting, but no phase flip. A spherical mask with ∼80 nm diameter was used for the 3D classification. The polyribosome classes were sorted out after ∼20 iterations of classification.

    Cookie Preference Center

    We use cookies which are necessary to make our site work. We may also use additional cookies to analyse, improve and personalise our content and your digital experience. For more information, see our Cookie Policy and the list of Google Ad-Tech Vendors.

    You may choose not to allow some types of cookies. However, blocking some types may impact your experience of our site and the services we are able to offer. See the different category headings below to find out more or change your settings.

    Manage Consent Preferences

    Strictly Necessary Cookies

    Always active

    These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

    Functional Cookies

    These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.

    Performance Cookies

    These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site.

    Targeting Cookies

    These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
